review:
This is yet another hybrid type of game, and Wars and Warriors: Joan of Arc shines with all the nice touches the developers put into it. You can fight alone, or command all your troops in battle. There's tons of equipment to use here too, from your standard swords to massive catapults and trebuchets. What it honestly feels like is an older Dynasty Warriors title set in France.

The game still looks great, even today. Soldiers are very detailed, as are the environments you'll be travelling through and fighting in. Big battles are impressive with slaughter on a massive scale, and all this done to a backdrop of siege weapons launching chunks of stone and other things at the enemy. The soundtrack is great and perfectly fits with the mood of the game. Swords clashing, men screaming, and stuff exploding and being crushed to bits help innumerably in making the battles exciting.

Average time to beat clocks in somewhere between 18 and 22 hours depending on how much of a completionist you are. Note this has no achievements as it by far predates that fad. Definitely one to give a go, especially if you're a fan of medieval settings and history itself in general. WaW goes on sale often for 75% off, worth a wishlist and nab at that price.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985409325', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 309, 'playtime_forever': 1201, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1201, 'last_played': 1615210179}
review:
Jeanne d'Arc/Joan of Arc is a medieval action-RPG set during the 100 years war. You can switch to a RTS camera, but if you don't like it, you only have to use this once to man a trebuchet and command it to attack a fortress. The main focus of the game is combat. You will speak with French citizens and do side missions, but for the most part, you will fight against the English and their allies. I quite like the combat and its many combo attacks, but some newcomers might get overwhelmed by the amount of enemies. Levelling up, increasing your stats and improving your gear and weapons is addicting and you will get very strong at the end of the game when one hero can potentially take out enemy castles on their own if you do it right. Joan of Arc is all about making good tactical decisions and be smart about it. Otherwise you make it harder for yourself. I recommend this game to players who are interested in a medieval setting with lots of fighting. 

Pros
++ combat 
+ addicting RPG elements
+ many castles and fortresses to take
+  You can take control of Jeanne d'Arc, Jean de metz, La Hire and the Duke of Alen√ßon. Each of them can lead a certain amount of troops whose number depend on their leadership skill
+ impressive engine at the time. The later missions are huge and place hundreds of enemies on the map. Only drawback is the short loading area message with a 1-2s delay at times
+ fun

Cons
- no resolution setting
- friendly AI will get stuck in narrow paths
- I would imagine this game is too repetitive for some people. On some missions, you have to kill hundreds of enemies
- abrupt ending

Gameplay tips
1. You can zoom out with your mouse wheel
2. turn off melee auto-targeting in the settings
3. increase HP to at least 200 as fast as possible (if you don't, English generals can take you out instantly), get EP (energy points) at least to 50 (becase eating apples gives you 50 EP), increase dexterity for heroes you want to become specialized archers and use most points on strength. I didn't see much point in levelling up defence or leadership. You can always wear some items to increase these stats anyway.
4. You can always open your inventory to pause your game and to eat food to get HP
5. Use arrows against the infamous English longbowmen. Don't be afraid to buy lots of arrows at blacksmiths. You will be swimming in gold anyway. Explosive arrows are useful to destroy gates and to silence masses of longbowmen fast in later levels. 
6. If you want your troops to stay alive, you need to have food in the troop inventory. Attacking castles head-on will use up your food reserves real quick though. Some of your men may die, but that is a sacrifice you are willing to make.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065619584', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 402, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1610566636}
review:
This was an instant buy when I saw this, I remember playing this game when I was a kid and although I wasn't quite the pro gamer then as I am now, I still tried my best to play this because it was so much fun back then considering the games that were on release at the time. It's a pretty challenging game on normal, autosave regularly.. and despite its somewhat clunky gameplay and awkward game engine, its simplicity makes it really easy to play and enjoy. Can be a little long winded as maps were large and although horses are avaiilable to mount, they don't give much of speed bonus. 

The core concept of the game though is classic, 3rd person hack'n'slash with RTS gameplay and a Hero levelling system... nothing too complicated. There's also an inventory management system for your Heroes and a sub section for the recruitable troops to your 'group', health items to heal yourself and revive fallen troops, and also merchants to trade with while exploring the towns, you can buy extra items, weapons and arrows for future missions. There's also a barracks where you can hire more troops as you progress later in the game.

Luckily I saw this on Steam when it was on sale but I'd recommend this game if you're looking for something a little old school and interesting content, but I'd still pay the ¬£5 for it, the game can be rather buggy like the AI but it's an old game and those kinda things are to be expected, not every game has perfect AI after all.

Tl;Dr - Good simple classic 7.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197985599207', 'num_games_owned': 195, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 702, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 316, 'last_played': 1575854772}
review:
[h1][b][i]A Diamond in the Rough[/i][/b][/h1]

To begin with, I should point out that I have a strange personal history with this game.
For altogether different reasons, 2008 was an important year for me, it also happens to be the year I bumped into this game. 
At that time, I was a teenager with a keen interest in the lore of Anglo-French rivalry stretching from the Late Mediaeval Period up till the end of the 19th century. And nowhere was this topic so important than in the so-called Hundred Years' War. 
Back in those days, there were very few games which were truly focused on that particular conflict (save for [i]Age of Empires II[/i] or [i]Medieval II: Total War[/i]), yet I nevertheless began digging in the hope of finding an entertaining game set in the 100 Yrs War. It must have been around February-March of that year that I downloaded the demonstration, which featured the first two levels in [i]Wars and Warriors: Joan of Arc[/i]. I liked what I saw, but my younger self was unfortunately unable to acquire the complete game.

Many years passed, and this game had turned into a fleeting memory. It became [i]"That cool game where you could play Joan of Arc and her acolytes"[/i]. Last year, in March 2018, I returned to a place I held dear and went on something of a nostalgic trip down memory lane. But I still couldn't remember that game...until it randomly popped out of nowhere as a suggestion on Steam.
It completely had flown under my radar for a decade, but even weirder was that I bought it exactly ten years to the month!

Coincidences and nostalgia aside, how exactly does it measure up today? Is it really worth buying?

Many will find this game off-putting at first. To call this game graphically and physically unrefined would be an understatement. A lot of the controls are clunky and the AI will often make you want to gnaw your nails off. The narration and voice acting is irritatingly quiet. But what it lacks in refinement, it makes up in variety of playstyles. You don't just get to play Joan of Arc, but a bunch of other nobles with different abilities. Another aspect of the game is its' large map and massive battles with open world elements. 

To put things in context, [i]Wars and Warriors: Joan of Arc[/i] was ahead of its' time when it came to portraying interactive battles. Not a lot of games could offer you the opportunity to pummel crowds of swordsmen and pikemen in 2004, this only really became more common in 2006 with games such as [i]Rise & Fall: Civilizations At War[/i] (sadly a forgotten game), that game however did the opposite and put a greater focus on Real Time Strategy instead.

Speaking of [i]Rise & Fall[/i], this game not only shares a common theme of massive interactive battles, [b]but it even shares some of the same music![/b] 
Having played [i]Rise & Fall[/i] long before I downloaded the [i]Joan of Arc[/i] demonstration, this was always something which struck me as extremely awkward. Indeed, Jason Graves placed some of his music from [i]Joan of Arc[/i] into [i]Rise & Fall[/i]. Which is alright I presume. However the [i]peplum-esque[/i] soundtrack will forever make me think of the very unmedieval Romans fighting Egyptians on the Nile or Alexander the Great chasing Persians throughout Mesopotamia instead.

As for what concerns historical accuracy, having extensively read on the 100 Yrs War I'll credit the game for shedding light on the de la Pole family, who were the lesser known opponents to the Armagnacs during the siege of Orl√©ans. But given the simplistic and cartoonish nature of the game I'm gonna give it a pass. It's a fun game and that's all that really matters.

Not a lot of games have really taken on the subject of the Hundred Years' War. The closest ones you can usually get are about the Black Death in which the conflict sits on the sidelines at best. [i]Bladestorm: The Hundred Years' War[/i], of [i]Dynasty Warriors[/i] accreditation, is the other real contender and a good one at that.

review:
Well, what can I say about this game...
Throughout the years I never forgot about this game, it's always been kind of stuck in my head as a timeless masterpiece.
I can remember playing it with so much passion as I was just a 7yo kid with not many friends (not that I have lots of them now). Everything about this game was mindblowing to me at the time: the graphics, the gameplay, etc... I couldn't ask for more. I went on playing it for a lot of time, until I lent the CD you needed to have to my cousin, so he could try it out for a day or two. Guess what happened: he lost it. It was heartbreaking for me and I still hadn't finish the game, so I had to went on living my life with a feeling of void in my soul because I didn't manage to complete it.
FFW to 2018.
One day I had a dream of that game, It was so intense it made me look for it on Steam and there I found it. I had to buy it so I could finish what I've let undone for all these years. Everything was great apart from the control/movement system which I didn't remember it to be that bad and cluncky.
Today I still haven't finished the game but it will soon be completed so I can get that feeling of void out of me.

I hope that my story convinced you to purchase this game that I love so much.
Have fun!

review:
I remember playing the demo for this game over ten years ago so it was a pleasant surprise to find it on Steam. Not only is this a third person action game, it also contains a number of real time strategy features. As well as this there is stat management and an inventory system, although I'm not sure that this game could be classified as an RPG. 

The combat is rather unsophisticated, but I found it enjoyable - it plays a lot like a Musou game, involving relatively large battles and combo-based attacks. That said, by modern standards the combat is a bit clunky, so if you can't stand old PC games, this might not be for you. Like many older games there is a lack of widescreen resolution options. There is a fix available, but I honestly had no problem just playing the game with the default settings, even if the aspect ratio was stretched from 4:3. 

Aside from playing as Joan of Arc, you can switch to a number of other characters with different weapons and movesets. The later campaign missions also introduce an RTS mode, which allows you to command units from a bird's eye view. I found that this game was the most fun when ignoring your troops as much as possible and simply going through the levels solo. You can even fill your inventory with arrows and play the game like a first person shooter. Joan's kill count was well into the thousands by the time I finished the game.

One of this game's main strengths is its scale - levels are large and open with plenty of forts and towns to capture as well as sidequests. There is even a day and night cycle. Completing all eight campaign missions took me over sixteen hours, so there is plenty of value for money. That said, the later levels can start becoming repetitive and often take over two hours to complete, so you should pace yourself accordingly. I also found the real time strategy component to be a weaker part of this game, mostly due to poor pathfinding. In one of the campaign missions I almost had to restart because Joan and some soldiers got themselves stuck on a narrow staircase and couldn't move out. The RTS mode is also a relatively small part of gameplay as supporting units can fend for themselves fairly well. Comparisons to Mount and Blade are fairly fitting, but don't expect too much. This game is at its best when you are mowing down hordes of enemies and not thinking too much about strategy.

I'm very glad to have had the chance to revisit this game, but it may not hold up for some people today. If you can tolerate the simple graphics and don't care too much about historical accuracy I would suggest that you give this very underrated game a look.

review: Kill Englishmen as Joan of Arc, in this 100 years old war historic fiction game. Yes. Kill Englishmen. They want the French throne, its the 1300's and using Joan, you single handedly get to thwart and kill them for trying. Relive battles from this epic war as akin to '' Dynasty Warriors'' to fight to level up your gear, your stats and gain a larger troops through 8 beefed up missions. I say ''beefed up'' because they start small, there are large maps and the sub quests are lengthy. Its not that quick and easy as you thought. WAR just isn't. The quests/ missions revolve around mainly the Bastard of Orleans and the defense of the French city and the villages around it. Use Joan or/and other French commanders she befriends to complete the missions. All have different fighting styles and weapons to your choosing. ( I stuck with Joan as being a pretty solid one handed sword user with top commander stats) . With French like classical music, sound effects of clashing armor and swords with accents, the game is pretty solid. The graphics and game play remind me of old Nintendo 64 games and runs rather well. The combat style sometimes can get jumpy, but its not so harsh. Yes, you have to learn game play and easily can be cut down by marauding English swords or pike men, but that's the skill part that needs to be learned. Overall a massive army hack and slash for you French, I think its a fun one to play along with Total War and other like games. Kinda of a Age of Empires first person thing going on...

author: {'steamid': '76561198037427689', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 141, 'playtime_forever': 1017, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 907, 'last_played': 1456077585}
review:
I'd like to point out that I'm recommending this game on a whim. It was overall a fun experience but only when you hit the last half of the game. This game is VERY buggy, has HORRIBLE AI and has overall bad balancing with enemies, specifically generals and archers/crossbowmen. I tend to write long reviews but, well, that's how it is. It's my personal experiences typed out for you to consider.

First off, the story. It's quaint. It's basically the whole Joan of Arc story, but it ends with a happy-note.[spoiler]Joan of Arc not dying and leaving to return to her home town and reunite with her friends and family instead of, y'know, being executed by the English.[/spoiler] It's 8 chapters/missions, the first two being short and the rest being 1-2 hours, at least. The story is well done and the ending is very satisfying. Definitely gives Joan of Arc the ending she deserved and it definitely makes Joan of Arc awesome, gameplay-wise. Probably one of the strongest generals in the game, other than Metz. More on that later.

Secondly, the music. The music in this game amazing. It has atmospheric sounds (e.g. dirt crunching beneeath feet, sound of metal armour hitting ground when moving, bird chirping, shouting and cheering sounds when fighting, etc.)that go very well with the game. The actual music itself has two side. The first side being the atmospheric-y non-combat music like this one, my personal favourite https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=96AFp2Z7SUE&index=5&list=PL6FC7ED1C9B1507AE Then there's the combat music like this, which is my personal favourite : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZZK2AUSdhlY&list=PL6FC7ED1C9B1507AE&index=2 If you listen to the combat music, at around 0:25 ish is when it really hits it hard. It just has a great feel to it for what the game's theme and atmosphere is. It's especially amazing when fighting the enemy generals. Overall, the music is satisfying if you like music that really goes for the home-run and fits into where it's placed.

Enough drooling over the music. Here we go. The graphics. The inevitable paragraph. The graphics are actually pretty amazing for its time (2004) and at the same time they aren't particularly anything to freak out over. The graphics fit the game and it doesn't hurt my eyes. Good enough for me.

Of course! An inventory system! You basically have 5 types of items : Weapons(main weapon for the hero's preference, e.g. maces for La Hire or polearms for Duke), armour(both aesthetic and pretty useful for damage reduction late-game), food(basically potions for health / energy), misc. items ( keys for chests and doors, letters for mostly story but also a few sub-missions), and ammo(for the crossbow/bow). Weapons consists of Base Damage + X% and bonuses for each attack such as +40% Down Attack, for killing downed enemies. The ranged weaponry is literally there for being the ranged weaponry and should only be used for taking out distance ranged enemies. Other than that, the inventory system is pretty simplistic.

Finally, the gameplay! This is where the game shines but also falls quite a bit. This is also where the wall of text is introduced. First off, I'm not exactly a "pro gamer" type of person but I'm also not horrible. I'm mediocre. The gameplay in this game is similar to dynasty warriors. It's a slash-a-sword-through-a-group-of-enemies-with-combos game. You can do both a normal attack and a power attack. The power attack uses up, well, energy and is significantly more powerful than your normal attacks, regardless of what bonuses you get. You have combos as well but for the most part they're there for the sake of being there. See, you can upgrade each individual attack/combo. The max level of an attack is level 10. Upgrading combos changes the damage by a minimal amount, so the best you can do is upgrade two attacks that are by far the most important ones. The first is the rush attack, which is THE quintessential forward dash. It also makes you invulnerable while perform it and costs very low energy (1 EP with a specific ring). The second attack is the "energy attack" which is basically an ultimate. It costs both HP and EP but is a ridiculously good crowd-control ability, mostly because it makes you invulnerable for the duration of the attack, knocks down everyone, and you move while performing it. Simple. Upgrade those and you'll do well... Against the normal enemies. Here's where the biggest issue of the combat comes into play : Ranged and Generals. Now, the ranged aren't *that* bad but the issue with them is that they constantly move around, shoot at a moderately fast rate (even the crossbowmen) and they generally don't die in one hit, being as durable as light infantry units. They can also make you stop in your tracks with one hit and any subsequent attacks knock you down. So, yeah, they're annoying. Cool. What about the generals? Simple! They're invulnerable when using their power attacks(which they can do an infinite number of times and in repetition one after the other), they deal a ton of damage(1-hit killed one of my generals with 108 HP SEVERAL TIMES, and the hit didn't even connect) and you can only really get hits in when you down them with a rush attack or sneaking hits in *immedietally* after they finish their power attacks. The good thing about all of this is that blocking can, well, block anything. You can defeat any of the generals 1-on-1 if you block-and-hit. That being said, it's horrible unbalanced and can make for a bad time if you don't know that. Yeah, that's it. Unbalanced generals and annoying ranged units.

A second finally, I'll talk about the siege and RTS aspects of the game. RTS is, well, RTS. I don't know how to explain this but somehow RTS makes the game easier. I don't know if it's because the AI goes ham on the combos and attacks and just bruteforces the combat but it makes it easier and it's one reason why the final mission is ridiculously easy, considering it's required that you use it to move some units. The siege mechanics in this game requires you to use RTS to move the units onto a siege weapon and then to move the actual siege weapon. Cannons can attack both units and buildings but the other siege weapons can only attack the buildings. You can either capture your own siege weapons from the English or you can build them at resource spots, which only the Duke can do. You're not even required to use the siege weaponry since you can buy explosive ammo which can take down gates, and generals are pretty good on their own. You can effectively solo any siege if you have the food and ammo for it.

Final finally, I promised to talk about the generals you can play as, so here we go. Joan of Arc is your all-around general at first-glance but she tends to have the most powerful attacks and her ultimate weapon has 5 socketable items that buff it up pretty nicely. She's definitely the spotlight. There's Jean Metz, who is basically Luke Skywalker with his attack speed, movement speed, and capability for high ranged damage(he starts off with decent dexterity). His power attacks are also VERY quick. There's the Duke, a halberd-wielding general that is required to make siege weapons and has a more AoE set of attacks. There's La Hire who takes the role of "lovable human boulder". His attacks are more AoE, especially his ultimate attack. His power attacks are in a circular formation. There's two unplayable characters : Bastard of Orleans and Prince Charles. They are playable in RTS mode but that's not so much "playable" as it is moving them around. So, who do I suggest for the "most powerful"? Metz. He's ridiculously OP with his attack speed and movement speed.

Inevitably I missed a few things but they would be very small things and not worth mentioning. Overall, the game was pretty decent but there were a few issues with it, like bad AI and invincible generals. If you can get past the small issues that litter this game, it's a pretty good Joan-Of-Kick-Ass game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053527041', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1640554590}
review:
When to buy this game? Think of it as medieval total war as a combined RPG/RTS that you can switch to on the fly. And if you've seen the well-rated movie 'the messenger' with Milla Jovovich (thats right, the resident evil chick) as Joan of Arc, you will definitely encounter many similarities and even in-game scenarios that happened in the movie too. 

On normal mode, the game is very easy to play. It's a typical old-school hack-n-slash revolving around using your left and right mouse buttons for combo's, and Q for blocking. Jumping and pressing C can be used for other powerful attacks. What makes the game enjoyable is the historically correct story (to my knowledge). Downside is the not optimally working collisions at times or some NPC's getting stuck (or even yourself, because NPC blocks path).

The castles and encampments in this game look great and you can decide to destroy them in RTS mode. The walls, towers and gates can actually break and be destroyed. Or you can decide to take it up close and personal and breach our way in and kill all the soldiers inside. 

There's a few classes of troops to choose from from light infantry and crossbowmen to polemen and macemen. you can assign all of those to your controllable commanders (the main characters, same as historic equivalents) or to the occasionally appearing less significant NPC commanders which look the same as regular units except they're donning goldplated armour.  The configurations stays both in RTS as in RPG mode.

In the first few missions the RTS element isn't introduced yet which doesn't really matter as you will not have a lot of units under your command thus playing in RPG mode makes sense. Later on in the game, you'll be able to build more troops, buy more armor, weapons and food and even build siege weapons.

Despite all the positive goodness, here a list of things that may downgrade the gaming experience:
- the poor collision registrations when striking enemies who are down. Instead, just use a power attack, you'll hit anyone down and standing. problem solved!
- getting stuck. it's annoying when your fellow soldiers get stuck especially if thereby they block your path. the only place it happens a lot is at Tourelles. if you go up into that fortress to destro the arbalests, make sure you have not too many units following you. or it will be impossible to go back via the narrow stairs and you can't jump off the wall.
- food shortage. There is only so much food in the game. You have a special inventory for yourself and the main characters, and a separate inventory for troops following those characters. with 15 troops under your commmand, it's doable. If you've got like 50 of them and they're under fire from siege weapons and arrows, food disappears within a minute. The only ways of getting more food is slaying enemies, slashing crates or buying from the food store, and the food store's food is NOT infinite. ... 
- The drag and drop interface. you can only move 1 item at a time. This becomes very problematic if youre in the heat of a battle and have to pause the game, to remove food items one by one to your troops inventory, to keep them alive -.-. Takes away from the gaming experience.


But yet, a game truly unique in its design with a nice story (you might learn something.) and oh yeah, checkout that movie joan of arc: the messenger with milla jovovich, you will recognize a LOT from that movie in this game.

review:
First review ever, have to warn, even at such a low price this is a laughably bad game.

Pros:  The music and voice acting are at least average for the dated title

Cons: Glitches ruined the entire experience from level 1.  Basic controls are ugly. Your sword often swings straight through common enemies to no effect.  The auto targeting gets me confused as it makes 180s to target enemies you aren't even engaging.  Enemy commanders go invincible whenever they attack, maybe suppose to make them harder or just waist more time dealing with them.  Attacking downed enemies only seems to work by luck as downed enemies tend to teleport to safety because of poor collisions.  Don't even try to ride a horse, you'll end up inside it surrounded by enemies you can't fight.  

If you feel like getting frustrated, give it a go, but I would recommend just playing a Dynasty Warriors title.

So, I first saw this game as a demo back when XP was the latest and greatest.....

It just as brilliant then as now.

Yes, the levelling system is grindy, and people get stuck on scenery from time to time, and just DON'T get on a horse (the controls are god-awful), but the game is FUN! Kill hundreds of englishmen (for once they're the bad guys!) and somehow it doesn't get old......

I've completed this game on easy, and the storyline is pretty good, with some optional side quests that generally give you a worth-while reward. The cut scenes use the same engine as the game (except the ending) and the dialogue is pretty good, even if bordering on the cheesy (and for those OCD out there the text doesn't match the speech). Also - the soundtrack, whilst it can eventually get a bit irritating, as it tells you there's an enemy just out of sight.... the soundtrack is magnificent.

I've had no issues with the game on Win7, so I can only presume those who are having issues are on other OS's.....

If you've played the demo before and liked it or you think you'll like it - buy it! If you don't think you will, buy it when it comes on sale, and you might just be a convert...

Very old but catchy and interesting game. For the first time, I've played this game when I was a child, and it gave to me tons of hours of fun. Now I can remind to myself of these epic and positive moments.

What's the game like? 
I can compare it with Dynasty Warriors with an actual story set in medieval times, with an inventory system and RTS elements. In simple words, it's like an RPG (but more or less linear) where you can select the character (not only Joan of Arc is available). The game has eight stages, and each stage has it's own huge battleground ‚Äì an entire map where you can feel yourself free to explore every corner. It‚Äôll take about 2-3 hours to finish it. There are even some sub-quests you can get from civilians. However, the main feature of the game is fighting and castle sieges. Command all your troops via RTS mode to besiege the castle or stronghold and switch your control to Joan of Arc to fight personally. Tons of enemies will try to separate your body from your head. You can lead your battle however you want: upgrade your main characters stats and lead an entire army to victory or fight alone 1vsDozens of bastards. 

On the other hand, the game will not impress you with its graphics but the story is still pretty nice and the soundtrack is great, and perfectly fits with the mood of the game. The sounds characters make, and the sounds of battle ‚Äì everything is perfect. 

It probably isn‚Äôt for everyone, but definitely one to give a go. I can recommend this.

I remember playing this game back in around 2007 or so, this game is very fun. If memories serve me correctly, mission 4 or misssion 5 is where the real fun begins, depends on your own opinions. Oh i recommend playing on the hardest difficulty, its VERY FUN that way. Completing Jeanne's St. Catherine de Fierbois with all 5 crosses is a nice way to kill englishmen. 
The cons of the game is that when you have all your Characters recruited full of units, or whenever you have alot of units under your command and following you whether in RTS mode of the standard third person, some units tends to get stuck around the environment and it gets annoying time to time. Not sure if steam version is any different tho.
A classic that should not be missed.
